item.title: Bridge returned error 400! (18885)
item.content:encoded:
Twitter @DenJustPro was unable to receive or process the remote website's content!
Error message: `The requested resource cannot be found!
Please make sure your input parameters are correct!
cUrl error: (0)
PHP error: `
Query string: `action=display&bridge=Twitter&context=By+username&u=DenJustPro&norep=on&nopic=on&noimg=on&format=Atom`
Version: `dev.2020-02-26`

  • Press Return to check your input parameters
  • Press F5 to retry
  • Check if this issue was already reported on GitHub (give it a thumbs-up)
  • Open a GitHub Issue if this error persists

pmaziere
item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: Denver Justice Project and other Community, local and state...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Denver Justice Project and other Community, local and state officials hosting a community breakout session on how to address community issues that exist in Auroraâ€™s 80010 ZIP Code. Primarily dealing with mental / behavioral health and the interactions and intersections that can further barrier community members dealing with these issues. (1601 N Havana st city of Aurora Adams county) (Village Exchange Center)

item.title: This is what happens when community is empowered to combat...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

This is what happens when community is empowered to combat injustice at its front and legislative lines. Huge props to community organizations and community memembers who put their bodies on the line for this young man and all victims and survivors of law enforce violence.

A grand jury has indicted the Aurora police officers who were involved in Elijah McClain's death two years ago.

cpr.org

Aurora Police Officers Indicted In The 2019 Death Of Elijah McClain

A grand jury has indicted the Aurora police officers who were involved in Elijah McClain's death two years ago.A grand jury has indicted the Aurora police officers who were involved in Elijah McClain's death two years ago.

item.title: Denver Justice ProjectThe Colorado SunJUST IN: Aurora officers and paramedics connected to Elijah McClain's death facing manslaughter and...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice ProjectThe Colorado Sun

JUST IN: Aurora officers and paramedics connected to Elijah McClain's death facing manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide charges.

Aurora police officers and paramedics who stopped Elijah McClain will be charged in his death, Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser said.

coloradosun.com

Grand jury returns 32-count indictment against Aurora officers, paramedics in Elijah McClainâ€™s death

Aurora police officers and paramedics who stopped Elijah McClain will be charged in his death, Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser said.Aurora police officers and paramedics who stopped Elijah McClain will be charged in his death, Colorado Attorney General Phil Weiser said.

item.title: Denver Justice ProjectThe Denver City Council plans to introduce an ordinance that would strip the mayor of his authority to appoint the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice ProjectThe Denver City Council plans to introduce an ordinance that would strip the mayor of his authority to appoint the independent monitor, giving the power instead to the Citizen Oversight

coloradopolitics.com

City Council to propose stripping mayor of appointment authority for independent monitor

The Denver City Council plans to introduce an ordinance that would strip the mayor of his authority to appoint the independent monitor, giving the power instead to the Citizen OversightThe Denver City Council plans to introduce an ordinance that would strip the mayor of his authority to appoint the independent monitor, giving the power instead to the Citizen Oversight

item.title: Denver Justice ProjectRyan N Beth Stone shared a link to the group: Colorado Justice Reform.Arrested on a Friday? For some Coloradans, that...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice ProjectRyan N Beth Stone shared a link to the group: Colorado Justice Reform.Arrested on a Friday? For some Coloradans, that may mean waiting in jail until Monday or a Tuesday for a bond hearing when courts are back open. Now, Democratic state lawmakers want to make it easier for people in jail to have their bail set and avoid getting stuck in lock-up longer than necessary.....

coloradosun.com

Colorado courts could soon be forced to hold bond hearings within 48 hours of someoneâ€™s arrest

Arrested on a Friday? For some Coloradans, that may mean waiting in jail until Monday or a Tuesday for a bond hearing when courts are back open. Now, Democratic state lawmakers want to make it easier for people in jail to have their bail set and avoid getting stuck in lock-up longer than necessary.....Arrested on a Friday? For some Coloradans, that may mean waiting in jail until Monday or a Tuesday for a bond hearing when courts are back open. Now, Democratic state lawmakers want to make it easier for people in jail to have their bail set and avoid getting stuck in lock-up longer than necessary.....
item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: Denver Justice ProjectDenver Justice ProjectHello DJP Community, It is such an honor to serve as the Denver Justice Project's first...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice ProjectDenver Justice Project

Hello DJP Community,

It is such an honor to serve as the Denver Justice Project's first Executive Director.

I have worked as a criminal justice oversight prac...titioner for the last six years serving as a manager for a youth outreach program at the Denver's Office of the Independent Monitor ("OIM"). I had the opportunity to watch how dynamic the Denver Justice Project ("DJP") was as it campaigned and successfully secured the OIM into the City Charter in 2016 and provide amendments in 2018. DJP has consistently exemplified how community power can transform law enforcement, promote racial justice, and, ultimately, end mass incarceration of our Black, Brown, and Indigenous community members.

As I write this letter of welcome, I grieve, again, as two more young men of color were murdered by law enforcement. Daunte Wright, 20, and Adam Toledo, 13, join the wrenching list of victims killed by an institution that does serve the collective liberation or justice for our communities. This week, we saw accountability as the murderer of George Floyd was convicted on all counts. I view this verdict as a turn in the tide towards justice, though, the work continues. We have a long road ahead as we live, breath and fight for a just, transformative world. I hope each of you are giving yourself the grace to grieve, to express your indignation, and to continue to advocate.

I also want to acknowledge how each of you have contributed to transforming policing in Denver. Thank you for your time and energy over the years. Because of this, DJP was able to solidify itself as an organization in our criminal justice advocacy community. My primary focus this first year is to build organizational capacity and continue our political and social advocacy work. Iâ€™m looking forward to showing up together to change law enforcement and the criminal justice system.

Please reach out if you have any questions or ideas about the vision for DJP.

In solidarity,
Gianina Horton

See More
item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: Hello DJP Community, It is such an honor to serve as the Denver...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Hello DJP Community,

It is such an honor to serve as the Denver Justice Project's first Executive Director.

I have worked as a criminal justice oversight practitioner for the last six years serving as a manager for a youth outreach program at the Denver's Office of the Independent Monitor ("OIM"). I had the opportunity to watch how dynamic the Denver Justice Project ("DJP") was as it campaigned and successfully secured the OIM into the City Charter in 2016 and provide amend...ments in 2018. DJP has consistently exemplified how community power can transform law enforcement, promote racial justice, and, ultimately, end mass incarceration of our Black, Brown, and Indigenous community members.

As I write this letter of welcome, I grieve, again, as two more young men of color were murdered by law enforcement. Daunte Wright, 20, and Adam Toledo, 13, join the wrenching list of victims killed by an institution that does serve the collective liberation or justice for our communities. This week, we saw accountability as the murderer of George Floyd was convicted on all counts. I view this verdict as a turn in the tide towards justice, though, the work continues. We have a long road ahead as we live, breath and fight for a just, transformative world. I hope each of you are giving yourself the grace to grieve, to express your indignation, and to continue to advocate.

I also want to acknowledge how each of you have contributed to transforming policing in Denver. Thank you for your time and energy over the years. Because of this, DJP was able to solidify itself as an organization in our criminal justice advocacy community. My primary focus this first year is to build organizational capacity and continue our political and social advocacy work. Iâ€™m looking forward to showing up together to change law enforcement and the criminal justice system.

Please reach out if you have any questions or ideas about the vision for DJP.

In solidarity,
Gianina Horton

item.title: Denver Justice Project was one of the first organizations around...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Denver Justice Project was one of the first organizations around the country to focus on the role power dynamics and influence of a district attorneys office in regards to these horrific crimesï¿¼ï¿¼.

item.title: 22nd and Oneida Southeast of the Oneida Town Centerï¿¼ Denver...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

22nd and Oneida Southeast of the Oneida Town Centerï¿¼

Denver Justice Project has worked with the family of all of these fallen Denver community members. In times like this itâ€™s difficult to find an outlet for healing, especially when folks around you do not have the sameï¿¼ traumatic experienceï¿¼. This is a big part of what Denver Justice Project was founded on... ï¿¼

When navigating interactions with law enforcement to the best possible outcomes here are some key things to keep in... mind when talking to police. Also this intersectional piece highlights not only art as activism but three of our fallen community members who were murdered by Denver police. Michael Marshall, Alonzo Ashley and Jessica ï¿¼ ï¿¼ Hernandez May they rest with honor.... keep watch for the video of the process to come..!!!

Big thanks to Chelsea Lewinski and Rubezilla for their talented hands..!!!!

item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: Nick Mitchellâ€˜s resignation from the position of the Office of...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Nick Mitchellâ€˜s resignation from the position of the Office of independent Monitor is something the community should be focused on. The office of independent monitor began after a young black boy who suffered from mental handicaps was murdered by Denver police in 2003, his name was Paul Childs.

This office was first staffed upon its creation by former office of independent monitor Richard Rosenthal. Upon Rosenthalâ€˜s resignation the office was assumed by Nicholas Mitchell and ...until very recently he has been the Second independent monitor to hold this position since the officeâ€™s inception.

This office had never been treated with the respect it deserves from the Department of safety. This office has struggled to get documents it needs to make an informed decision on cases of officer misconduct, access to video footage, and feedback from the manager of safety and chief of police in a timely fashion.

In 2016, Denver Justice Project ran an initiative that made it to the ballot that would codify the office of independent monitor in the Denver city charter as it currently at the time it existed in ordinance only meaning the mayor could dissolve the office without input from the community. Amendment 2B passed later that year solidifying the office permanently unless community voted to dissolve it. There is still much work to be done on behalf of community to strengthen this office. Now even more pressing is who will take this role next.

https://www.westword.com/â€¦/denver-independent-monitor-resigâ€¦

See MoreHe's taking a court-appointed position overseeing L.A. jails.

westword.com

Nick Mitchell Leaving Job as Denver Independent Monitor

He's taking a court-appointed position overseeing L.A. jails.He's taking a court-appointed position overseeing L.A. jails.

item.title: Huge thanks to the talented Chelsea Lewinski and RubeZilla for...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Huge thanks to the talented Chelsea Lewinski and RubeZilla for making this venture happen. Here is just a peek of part of whatâ€™s coming. Also keep watch for the video of the process and project.... Knowing Your Rights is only part of the battle.

On the left is Alanzo Ashley who was killed at the Denver zoo by Denver police in 2011.

And to his right is Jessica Hernandez Who was shot and killed by Denver police in 2015 in an alleyway after police where called because they where sleeping in their car.
item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: The Denver Citizen Oversight Board is hosting an important...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

The Denver Citizen Oversight Board is hosting an important conversation about the Office of the Independent Monitor's report on DPD's dangerous and irresponsible response to the George Floyd protests this summer and the recommendations on what needs to change tonight at 6pm. We encourage you all to tune in and let DPD and the Hancock administration know how many Denverites expect accountability for police violence and overreach.
More info in the COB's FB event here: https://fb.me/e/1NMUQvbjr
item.author: Denver Justice Project

item.title: Huge thanks to Maisha Fields and all the folks at the Dayton...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Justice Project

Huge thanks to Maisha Fields and all the folks at the Dayton Opportunity Center for allowing Denver Justice Project and Youth Empowerment Agency ï¿¼ï¿¼ along with other folks from the Business Empowerment Networkï¿¼ to host a know your rights traininï¿¼g where we educated over 20 young people ranging from 6-16 on how to navigate interactions with law-enforcement to the best possible outcomeï¿¼.
